awd_titl_txt: Heegaard Floer homology: algebraic curves, knot genera, and double null-concordance
awd_abstract_narration:
Problems related to finding solutions to polynomials equations arose in ancient Greek mathematics.  The advent of coordinate geometry led to a better understanding of the nature of such problems, and the introduction of complex numbers provided an important new perspective.   In this way, determining the nature of a curve in the plane defined as the solution set of a polynomial equation with two variables is related to the problem of understanding surfaces in four dimensional space. The Principal Investigator is investigating topological properties of the surfaces that arise.  It has been observed that the local properties of these surfaces relate to knots; this project includes continuing research on four-dimensional aspects of classical knot theory. Coupled with his research in knot theory,  the Principal Investigator  maintains a website devoted to providing students and researchers access to current information about knots.  In addition to assisting people working in knot theory (both pure mathematicians and applied), the website serves as an important educational tool, reaching students around the world.

A homogenous polynomial equation with three variables defines a complex curve in two-dimensional complex projective space.  Recent work of the Principal Investigator, done jointly with Borodzik and Borodzik-Hedden, has restricted the possibilities for singularities in the case that the curve is topologically a sphere or torus.  The approach was to understand the Heegaard Floer homology of the boundary of a neighborhood of the curve.  Constraints on these homology groups arising from the complement of the curve in turn constrain the singularities the arise.  Developing this further is one goal of the Principal Investigator's research. In studying singularities of complex curves, one is led naturally to studying the four-genus of knots.  When restricted to torus knots, the topic is well understood.  Working with Van Cott, the Principal Investigator  is applying a combination of classical techniques and Heegaard Floer theory to understand the four-genus of connected sums of torus knots, beginning with linear combinations of a pair of torus knots.  Independent of this work, the Principal Investigator is also trying to extend his previous work with Gilmer concerning the non-orientable four-genus of knots; one goal is to apply Heegaard Floer theory to build new examples of knots with large nonorientable four-ball genus.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
From the years 2015 through 2022, Professor Livingston published 21 papers that were related to knot theory, the study of knotted curves in space.  Most of the papers concerned issues that arise when knot theory is viewed from a four-dimensional perspective.  As described in the original proposal, the methods that were used included such modern tools as Heegaard Floer theory.  
    An application of Professor Livingston's research, as outlined in the proposal, was the study of what are called "algebraic curves."  His initial work on this (with Maciej Borodzik) found applications of knot theory methods to the study of "rational algebraic curves." Roughly stated, this concerns describing the solution set to equations f(x,y) = 0, where f is a polynomial.  This thread of his research culminated in joint work with Borodzik and Matthew Hedden in which the prior results with Borodzik were greatly generalized.
    One aspect of the research was the study of symmetries of knots; some knots have very symmetric diagrams and others seem to be very asymmetrical.  One paper focused on  relationships between knots and their mirror images.  Two others focused on knot reversal, basically changing the direction of the knot. One of the highlights of the research was the discovery that when one moves from knots to links (formed from several curves in space) certain types of symmetry cannot occur.  This resolved a long-standing question in the field.
    The grant included support funds for the website KnotInfo.  Professor Livingston created this knot theory website in 2004 and now maintains it with Professor Allison Moore (Virginia Commonwealth University).  In addition to enhancing the database, a major effort was put into improving the background structure to ensure that longevity of the site.
    This site KnotInfo plays an important role in Professor Livingston's outreach efforts.  It is one of the most valuable online resources for knot theory researchers.  In the last survey, it was found that each months the site was contacted by people at almost 100 universties and research centers.
    With regards to the educational component of the grant, Professor Livingston served as dissertation director for one graduate student during the grant.  This was Samantha Allen, now at Duquesne University.  He also worked with several other advanced graduate students at Indiana University.  Through his work on KnotInfo, Professor Livingston interacted with other graduate student in a variety of ways.  In particular, students often discover new data that can be included in the website, sometimes in the context of their own thesis research.


Last Modified: 11/07/2022
Modified by: Charles Livingston
